Award.AwardTitle: Mathematics as a FirstSTEP to Success in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Difficulties in passing required mathematics courses often discourage young STEM majors, leading them to leave STEM for other fields. Based on the success of STEPMT: STEPping up Undergraduate Research at Middle Tennessee State University, the Type 1-B Mathematics as a FirstSTEP to Success in STEM project focuses on interventions addressing math deficiencies which place freshman STEM majors who are at risk of not graduating as STEM majors into an intensive academic and student support environment. FirstSTEP Is a broad-based project that targets students from all STEM disciplines who are underprepared in mathematics.

First-time, full-time freshman students, who are at-risk based on mathematics ACT test scores, participate in an intensive two-year program that includes a mathematics bridge program before their freshman year followed by an individualized study plan using technology and human interventions. The cohorts of students complete pre-calculus in the fall semester and Calculus I in the spring semester along with a one-credit semester during the academic year. The one-credit course adopts and implements an effective professional seminar model in which students learn the knowledge and skills associated with successful STEM professionals. During the summer between their freshman and sophomore years, cohorts participate in a one-month, intensive, inquiry-based exploration utilizing mathematics that is connected to their major field of study. During the sophomore year, the cohorts of students enroll in a one-credit semester designed to develop skills to prepare them for undergraduate research and to mentor the next freshman cohorts.

In addition, First STEP builds on current projects aimed at increasing graduation rates of all STEM majors by addressing the high DFW rates in pre-calculus and calculus. Pedagogies, such as Peer Led Team Learning, stretch courses, and individualized study plans, are used and tested during the summer bridge program and then are integrated into pre-calculus and Calculus I courses for all students, STEM majors and students in other majors. With changes in the courses, more aspiring STEM majors, who are underprepared in mathematics, experience success in their mathematics courses and consequently continue in their STEM studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematics as a First Step toward Success in STEM (FirstSTEP) was designed to study strategies that improve retention and graduation of STEM majors who enter college unprepared to succeed in mathematics. We learned that while poor mathematics preparation is a significant barrier to success in STEM, students will not succeed if you address these deficits and ignore family and life issues.  We learned that students who are not prepared to succeed in college algebra (Math ACT < 22), can succeed in pre-calculus with proper support. We learned that with appropriate pre-course work and support during the course, these at-risk students can succeed in pre-calculus and calculus 1 at rates higher than the general population of students (69% to 60% for pre-calculus and 58% to 57% for calculus 1).  They also can be retained in STEM into their second year at a rate higher than the general population of freshman STEM majors (52% to 45%). A two-week summer math bridge increases scores of pre-calculus readiness by 35 percentage points, enough to enable success in the first half of pre-calculus. At-risk students need totoring and hand-holding throughout the pre-calculus course to be successful. We learned that a 3-week team-based research experience in the summer between their freshman and sophomore years increases self-efficacy and self-confidence more than the entire freshman year of course work.  Furthermore, we learned that young, at-risk STEM majors can be successful in research to the point of making presentations at national conferences, and occasionally, publishing their research. This project produced 88 student preentations, 19 at the national and international level, and six student publications at the national and international level. We also reaffirmed that curricular reform, to be successful, must begin at the faculty level.
